Nach dem Rekordstart ins Jahr 2017 mit vielen neuen Mitgliedern und über 100 neuen Partnern gibt es jetzt auch einen finanziellen Schub: Unsere Partner von Holtzbrinck Ventures GmbH untermauern das in uns gesetzte Vertrauen im Rahmen einer weiteren Finanzierungsrunde! 🏋️  Was das für dich bedeutet? Wir können noch besser unser Ziel verfolgen, deine Stadt zu deinem Sportclub zu machen! Freue dich über weitere Standorte, neue Sporarten, neue Funktionen in unseren Apps und vieles mehr!  Danke, dass du uns auf unserem Weg zum größten, flexibelsten und vielfältigsten Sportangebot Deutschlands begleitest!

2017 at Urban Sports Club continues to get better and better.   Our City Managers have really went all in: Back in January, we presented you about 50 new partners, now there's even 60 locations where you can check in in February!  Which partner did you discover for yourself, who would you like to see join our network? We appreciate your feedback!

Motion Break and Workplace Health Promotion surely are known words at your workplace. But what are actually the most popular sports amongst colleagues, where can you make bonds with new colleagues the quickest?
The Tanzprojekt München - an integral part in the cultural life of Munich since 1975. The offer in the center for contemporary dance is diverse, enrichened by an international guest teacher program.
Sweet and deep YOGA is Romarei's Yoga school in Kreuzberg. As sweet and deep are the experiences that you will have in her Yin and Vinyasa Yoga classes! :)
A secret top address of Munich's Yoga studios, nicely located at Glockenbachviertel in a nice courtyard: Small, gorgeous and personally - it is Jaya Yoga!
In Paris, where Laurence Chaperone was born, Floorbarre is a very well known and popular method from the ballet dance. But, of course, it´s great fun for all. Visit her and give it a try! :)
Amateur and professional fighters are welcome at MFC_munichfightclub! Boxing, Thai boxing, MMA or Brazilian Jiu Jitsu are on the program.
FAM München - this means Free Arts of Movement and combines Parcours, Slacklining, Trampoline, Breakdance, Capoeira... give it a try at our new locations!
Mattengold is the new studio for yoga and Pilates in Stuttgart-Wangen, located right near Heinrich-Hermann-Areal!

Our friends from Kadampa Meditationszentrum Berlin have launched a new session series - On wednesday evenings, you can refresh your mind in up to two meetings with "14 meditations for a meaningful & happy life".
We support Germany's first professional beach volleyball club, the Hauptstadt Beacher. And we already had a peek into their season preparation for our latest blog...
IKYA Meditation - Germany meets Mika Yoga - a splendid combination is waiting for you on this special event.  You can register via pm to the organisers or by mail to info@sandranicolepfaller.de

Customized functional training, that's what you'll find in at Harmonic FIT. Small groups of a maximum of 10 persons are guaranteed. Workouts will be done with your body weight only and with individual care - depending on your own training goal!
Ballett und andere Tänze kannst du bei der Ballettschule Esther in München erlernen!

On February 25th, the motto at Südbloc - Boulderhalle Berlin will be "All you can top!" Anyone can participate - Whoever has topped the most boulders within two hours will be crowned the winner. Sounds like you will have heaps of fun!
150 different climbing routes, bouldering, slacklining at a height of 7 metres and more - Kletterhalle Köln-Dellbrück has so much to offer!
At Sportpark Nord in Nuremberg, you'll find squash, badminton, table tennis, wellness and so much more, all in one location. Perfect to keep your shape!
160 sqm for body and soul - at beautiful Kursraum in Gereonsviertel you work out with experienced coaches and physiotherapists. Pilates, Yoga, Functional and Core Training are in the program!
Can't get enough of yoga? Awesome! In Friedenau and Kreuzberg, you can now experience a powerful, flowing yoga style! Classes run for 8-10 weeks but you can chip in at any time.
Workshops, tryout classes, a night of dancing and many surprises: SORRISO Sport & Tanz celebrates its anniversary!

Among the highlights are RideBerlin and another Holmes Place Berlin - Bismarckstraße, as well as the studios of Patrick Broome Yoga in Munich. Cologne has a new boulder option in Canyon Chorweiler while Nuremburg and Augsburg add more options.
Wir könnten hier an dieser Stelle etwas Verstärkung gebrauchen! Bewirb dich als Community Manager bei uns :)
2. Woche rum und die guten Vorsätze können schon wieder bis nächstes Jahr warten? Nicht mit uns! Wir haben für dich die besten Tipps aus den Reihen des Urban Sports Teams gesammelt.

Neu: Massage bei Enso Yoga Enso Yoga in Mitte bietet jetzt auch Massage an. Als L-Mitglied kannst du nun hier einen 20-minütigen Termin per E-Mail vereinbaren. Von wegen trist und grau - der November ist der Rekordmonat im Urban Sports Club! Über 60 neue Partner und Standorte konnten unsere City Manager in den vergangenen Wochen dazugewinnen. Allen voran natürlich in Nürnberg, das als neue Urban Sports Club-Stadt zum 1. Dezember gestartet ist. Ein weiteres Highlight sind die KölnBäder, die gleich mit ihrem gesamten Angebot dazugekommen sind. Aber auch in Hamburg (hier gibt es mit der INDOO Eisarena Planten un Blomen Hamburg und Kadampa Meditationszentrum Hamburg gleich zwei neue Sportarten), München und Stuttgart hat sich einiges getan. In Frankfurt gab es zudem mit der Ten Weeks Fitness ein schönes, zentral gelegenes Studio dazu.

Pünktlich zum Beginn des weltbekannten Christkindlesmarkt bieten wir den sportlichen Ausgleich zu Lebkuchen und Glühwein: Den Urban Sports Club gibt es jetzt endlich auch in Nürnberg! Und mit Fitness, Yoga, Klettern oder Bouldern, EMS und Kampfsport u.vm. bieten wir dir bereits jetzt 21 Sportarten an 29 Standorten! Falls du Freunde in Franken hast, kannst du die frohe Botschaft gerne teilen.

Großartige Neuigkeiten für alle Kölner: Ab Donnerstag um 8.30 Uhr (1. Dezember) kannst du zum Schwimmen, Saunabaden und Eislaufen bei allen 13 Standorten der KölnBäder als Urban Sports Club-Mitglied einchecken! (Check-In ist NUR per App möglich). http://bit.ly/2grLVc0

Am Sonntag ist 1. Advent! Und da schenken ja bekanntlich genauso viel Freude macht wie beschenkt werden, bringen wir nun diese Pakete auf den Weg. Was das heißt? Viele neue Partner und Standorte für dich. Und es gibt Bonuspunkte, wenn du unsere City Managerin Annelie findest!

Happy birthday to multi-directional drummer Jack DeJohnette​, 75 years old today. Jack has appeared on more ECM discs than any other musician. His first recording for the label was 'Ruta and Daitya', duos with Keith Jarrett​ in 1971. Since then there have been many, many highlights, from the brilliant solo album 'Pictures' to the Gateway trio, 'New Directions' and 'Special Edition' and recent collaborations with Ravi Coltrane and Matthew Garrison​. There is more of Jack’s great drumming in our autumn programme, too. Details soon.

Bill Frisell's Music and Thomas Morgan’s new duo recording 'Small Town' keeps getting rave reviews on both sides of the Atlantic during these summer weeks:  “This is a kind of collaboration that is on a different plateau of interaction and interplay, and as such, it is a joy to listen over and over again”, states Nenad Georgievsky on Allaboutjazz.com, while Peter Hobart in the UK’s Financial Times praises the albums “warm and grace”. Germany’s two leading daily papers, Süddeutsche Zeitung and FAZ.NET - Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung have both dedicated the album extensive reviews. And in the Chicago Reader writer Peter Margasak marvels: “The connection between these two musicians is so sublime it’s as if they’re creating a sculpture right before our ears. I’m looking forward to getting lost within it.”  Get the album here: http://bit.ly/2oIfIDz

'Places' by Jan Garbarek, feat. Bill Connors, John Taylor and Jack DeJohnette has been reissued on 180g Vinyl and Hi-Res Download!  Get the LP: http://bit.ly/2u3VRSk  Recorded in 1977 in Oslo, 'Places' was an important album for Norwegian saxophonist Jan Garbarek, and – with its stellar line-up including Americans Jack DeJohnette and Bill Connors – one that also drew significant attention in the US. “How does Garbarek set up his floating dreamlike moods?” asked DownBeat Magazine, and proceeded to itemize components of this “eerie, desolate, bleak” music: “John Taylor plays sustained legato chords, much more like Lutheran church music than, say, Jimmy Smith. The organ provides a backdrop of shifting sonorities…DeJohnette’s playing is airy, concentrating on cymbals, creating shimmering webs of rhythm. Up front is Garbarek, the only real solo voice. He speaks slowly, with attention to detail. He has a fine sense of pitch, so that when he ornaments a note with a bend, a slur or a grace note, it is done precisely, consciously…” The album stands as one of Garbarek’s strongest statements as a player. Reviewing Places in 1978, Don Heckman wrote in High Fidelity that Garbarek was “easily the best sax player to emerge from Europe in the last decade.”

"Inland Sea is a beautifully textured soundscape not tied to any time or place. With airy tones and earthy twangs, [Stephan Micus] grows something both worldly and otherworldly—mysteriously alien but with something familiar and organic underlying it all. It makes for an atmospheric listen as alluring as it is unclassifiable." (All About Jazz) "Inland Sea" is available now!

San Francisco Chronicle raves about György Kurtág's "Complete Works For Ensemble And Choir": “to listen to the chamber works packed into this gorgeous three-disc set — an array of instrumental, vocal and choral music all crafted with unerring sensitivity by conductor Reinbert de Leeuw — is to marvel anew at Kurtág’s versatility and range. The solo vocal music boasts its familiar spiky allure, as Kurtág spins improbably sparkling filigree out of the leaps and angular lines of traditional modernism.”  Amazon http://smarturl.it/KurtagComplete_Amz  iTunes http://smarturl.it/GyorgyComplete_iTu

Stephan Micus est un musicien extraordinaire qui collecte des instruments venus du monde entier, qui apprend à en jouer et qui compose sa propre musique à partir d’eux. Il en joue rarement de manière traditionnelle et le plus souvent les adapte à son style de jeu en en modifiant la structure. Son but n’est jamais de s’inscrire dans des univers sonores traditionnels mais bien d’en créer de nouveaux. Découvrez dès maintenant l'album « Inland Sea » déjà disponible. ►https://ECM.lnk.to/InlandSeaAlbum

ECM is Record Label of the Year and Manfred Eicher Producer of the Year in the DownBeat International Critics Poll.   This is the ninth time in recent history that ECM and its producer have topped the poll, on this occasion by a large margin. The 3-CD set of György Kurtág’s  Complete Works for Ensemble and Choir has already met with a 5-star review in The Guardian. “György Kurtág, who turned 91 in February, is now the grand old man of European music, and perhaps the greatest living composer,” writes Andrew Clements. “This magnificent set brings together some of Kurtág’s greatest achievements and is performed with devotional precision and commitment… De Leeuw, his ensemble and the Netherlands Radio Choir (in the choral works) are fabulously lucid guides… The set is fastidiously presented; ECM’s informative essays regularly put to shame the PR puffery that can masquerade as sleeve notes from the so-called major labels. Kurtág’s exquisitely precise music, wasting nothing, demands that attention.”

New release: 'Inland Sea' by Stephan Micus  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2s8SVTb Get the album: http://bit.ly/2s8M2Ry iTunes: http://bit.ly/2sFZqOw  'Inland Sea' is Stephan Micus’ 22nd solo album for ECM, each one taking his audience on musical journeys to far-flung places and unique sound worlds. For decades, he has been travelling, collecting and studying musical instruments from all over the world and creating new music for them. Micus often combines instruments from different cultures and continents that would never normally be played together, adapting and extending them, and rarely playing them in a traditional manner. The instruments then become a cast of characters that help tell the particular story of that album. While he plays nine different instruments on 'Inland Sea', the lead role belongs to the nyckelharpa – a keyed fiddle from Sweden, with an array of other instruments and vocals providing layers and textures throughout.

New release: 'Bells for the South Side' by Roscoe Mitchell   Learn more: http://bit.ly/2tuBvhA Get the CD: http://bit.ly/2r2S8A0  iTunes: http://bit.ly/2rU6kNf   Roscoe Mitchell contrasts and – for the first time – combines the sounds and distinctive characters of his four trios in an exhilarating double album recorded at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago. Multi-instrumentalist and composer Mitchell had been invited to premiere new music at the museum, in the context of the exhibition 'The Freedom Principle', which celebrated the directions in music and art set in motion by the AACM on Chicago’s South Side. He offers what amounts to a composer self-portrait in continually changing colours and textures, reflecting on his own history while looking toward the future. Two pieces – including the title composition – draw upon the full percussion instrumentarium of the Art Ensemble of Chicago – a panorama of gongs, bells, rattles, sirens, hand drums and more. Along the way there are remarkable contributions by all participants, among them a lyrical bass guitar feature for Jaribu Shahid on “EP 7849”, a heart-dilating solo by Tani Tabbal on “Cards for Drums”, an extended trumpet feature for Hugh Ragin on the title track, evocative and atmospheric electronics from Craig Taborn and James Fei on “Red Moon in the Sky”, and plenty of Mitchell’s powerhouse saxophones throughout, from the piercing sopranino down to the mighty bass sax. The performance is concluded with “Odwalla”, the Mitchell-composed theme song of the Art Ensemble.

'Solstice' by Ralph Towner feat. Jan Garbarek, Eberhard Weber and Jon Christensen is reissued on 180g Vinyl!  Get the LP: http://bit.ly/2qO9qjs  DownBeat Magazine: “Solstice inspires through its expressive openness… revealing depth of texture, nuance and meaning.”  Perfect Sound Forever: “The LP is not only one of the moodiest ever published by ECM, but by anyone.”   'Solstice', recorded 1974, belongs to the great early production projects of ECM, with a new band formed in the studio. It’s the first of Towner’s recorded encounters with the European players, and this US-Norwegian-German quartet has a character all its own. Ralph’s synthesis of classical guitar technique and jazz improvisational skills inspires all participants on now-famous tunes including “Nimbus” and “Oceanus”. (Many future associations grew out of this meeting, including the Garbarek/Towner collaboration on Dis, and the integration of Eberhard Weber into the Jan Garbarek Group, and of Jon Christensen into Weber’s Colours band.)

New Release: 'Small Town' by Bill Frisell & Thomas Morgan   +++ Available on CD + 180g LP +++   Read more here: http://bit.ly/2qVMmCG  Buy the album at a retailer nearby or here: http://smarturl.it/SmallTown_Amz   Small Town presents guitarist Bill Frisell's Music and bassist Thomas Morgan in a program of duets, the poetic chemistry of their playing captured live at New York’s hallowed Village Vanguard. DownBeat Magazine devotes the actual cover story to Bill Frisell and states that "this intimate duo outing has the guitarist and his sympathetic partner creating a near-telepathic bond". The old-time folk and bluegrass tune “Wildwood Flower” has its place here, alongside a James Bond movie theme, tributes to veteran master musicians Lee Konitz and Andrew Cyrille, Paul Motian’s “It Should Have Happened A Long Time Ago”, and original pieces by Bill and Thomas. If ever an album had something for everybody, this is it. Both charming and creative, Small Town should not be missed.

Get the LP: http://bit.ly/2pRZVnP  The Survivors’ Suite, recorded in 1976, is the crowning achievement of Keith Jarrett’s “American Quartet” with Dewey Redman, Charlie Haden and Paul Motian, and one of the all-time enduring masterpieces in the ECM catalogue.   Melody Maker: “The Survivors’ Suite is a brilliantly organized and full-blooded work which provides the perfect setting for all four talents. This is a very complete record. It creates its own universe and explores it thoroughly, leaving the listener awed and satisfied... An unashamedly ardent album, Jarrett’s very finest.”   The Wire: Adventures In Modern Music: “The labyrinthine composition seems to redefine ‘intensity’ each time it turns a corner. The drive toward the climax of Side Two is among the most moving in modern music, Dewey Redman absolutely titanic over the surging rhythms.”

New release: 'Cross My Palm With Silver' by Avishai Cohen   Learn more: http://bit.ly/2pKuXwS Get the album: http://bit.ly/2otTC8o  A year after his impressionistic, critically-lauded ECM debut 'Into The Silence', trumpeter Avishai Cohen Music’s 'Cross My Palm With Silver' introduces a programme of new pieces which put the focus on the ensemble, on teamwork, with a quartet of the highest calibre. The adroit, almost telepathic interplay among the musicians allows Avishai Cohen to soar, making it clear why he is one of the most talked-about jazz musicians on the contemporary scene. “All of these people together are my dream team”, says the charismatic trumpeter of fellow players Yonathan Avishai, Barak Mori and Nasheet Waits, who share his sense for daring improvisation and his feeling for structure. “I feel we’re in a perfect place with the balance. It’s open and there’s so much room for the improvisation to take the music any place we can. At the same time the composition is very specific and the vibe is very direct and thought about.” As with 'Into The Silence', 'Cross My Palm With Silver' was produced by Manfred Eicher at Studios La Buissonne in the south of France. It is issued on the eve of a major European tour, with concerts in France, Italy, Spain, Luxembourg, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands.

'Conference of the Birds' by the Dave Holland Quartet is reissued on 180g Vinyl!   Get the LP: http://bit.ly/2q22ao6   It had been preceded by ECM duo albums with Barre Phillips and with Derek Bailey as well as the cooperative band Circle’s great 'Paris Concert', but 'Conference of the Birds', recorded in 1972, was Dave Holland’s first album as a full-fledged leader. An album of driving, progressive jazz it is also of historical significance as the only occasion when Sam Rivers and Anthony Braxton, two of the music’s most strikingly original saxophonists, recorded together. Inside Dave’s compositions they could meet – if briefly – and share ideas. This summit meeting received raves from the press. “If you’ve found the new music lacking in swing, cohesion and variety, get to this album,” insisted DownBeat Magazine in a five star review. “It’s Holland’s date but each man contributes equally. The six Holland tunes offer great improvisational frameworks, and his bass playing, both arco and pizzicato, couldn’t be better… Don’t miss this one.”  Photos: Roberto Masotti

Stay tuned for 'Cross My Palm With Silver', the new album of Avishai Cohen Music – to be released this Friday (May 5th) on CD | 180g Vinyl | Download.   Preorder the album: http://bit.ly/2otTC8o  The album release coincides with an extensive European tour, starting today in Luxembourg.

Master clarinettist Eduard Brunner has died in Munich. He was 77 years old. Born in Basel in 1939, Brunner graduated from its conservatory at 18, and went on to study in Paris with Louis Cahuzac. At 20 he was working as an orchestral musician in Basel and playing chamber music with Heinz Holliger and Aurèle Nicolet. Subsequent chamber music partners would include Gidon Kremer, Alfred Brendel, Natalia Gutman, Yuri Bashmet and Kim Kashkashian, among many others. With Kashkashian, Brunner appeared on the album 'Hommage à R. Sch.', recorded 1992-94, the first ECM disc to feature music of György Kurtág (juxtaposed with compositions of Robert Schumann). Eduard Brunner had close relationships with many contemporary composers, from Gia Kancheli to Helmut Lachenmann, and a number of them wrote music for him. He appeared as a soloist on Kancheli’s 'Caris Mere' album, performing Midday Prayers with the Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra under Dennis Russell Davies. And he played Lachenmann’s 'Dal niente' on the brilliant – and highly influential – solo clarinet album of the same name, alongside pieces by Scelsi, Boulez, Stravinsky, Stockhausen and Isang Yun. Eduard Brunner can also be heard in ECM’s Edition Lockenhaus recordings, playing music of Stravinsky (with Gidon Kremer and Aloys Kontarsky) and Shostakovich (with Irena Grafenauer and Oleg Maisenberg). New release: 'Nightfall' by Quercus Learn more: http://hyperurl.co/y9qq9s Get the album: http://hyperurl.co/orfr1k   Quercus’s self-titled ECM debut won the album-of-the-year award of the German Record Critics in 2013, was widely praised  by the  international press, and especially celebrated in Britain where June Tabor has long reigned as “the dark voiced queen of English folk music” (to quote The Times). Folk and jazz and chamber music become one in Quercus’s world, where recontextualizing of material is part of the process, prompting listeners to pay heightened attention even to familiar songs. Nightfall opens with the most famous of farewells in “Auld Lang Syne”, and gently breathes new life into it, leading us into a programme that includes Bob Dylan’s “Don’t Think Twice”, the jazz standard “You Don’t Know What Love Is” and the West Side Story ballad “Somewhere”, as well as original compositions by Huw Warren and Iain Ballamy and songs from British folk tradition, in stark and moving new arrangements.

New release: 'Titok' by Ferenc Snétberger  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2owXUb8 Get the album: http://bit.ly/2pKEe5A  Hungarian guitarist Ferenc Snétberger made a lot of new friends with his ECM solo debut 'In Concert' (“a beautiful, assured performance” – All About Jazz) and will make many more with 'Titok', which features his trio with Swedish bassist Anders Jormin and US drummer Joey Baron. Recorded at Oslo’s Rainbow Studio in May 2015 and produced by Manfred Eicher, it’s a warm and involving album, with an emphasis on intensely melodic improvisation and interaction which draws the listener gently into its sound-world. The rapport between Snétberger and Jormin is evident from the outset, as both guitar and bass explore the contours of Ferenc’s compositions. Throughout, Joey Baron’s drums and cymbals provide shading and texture with restraint and subtlety.

New release: 'Find the Way' by Aaron Parks | Ben Street | Billy Hart  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2pL3NGl Get the album: http://bit.ly/2p2ywhp  For the second ECM album by Aaron Parks – following the solo release 'Aborescence', which JazzTimes praised as “expansive, impressionistic… like a vision quest” – the prize-winning pianist has convened a trio featuring bassist Ben Street and drummer Billy Hart. The rhythm pair, which also teams in Hart’s hit quartet for ECM, blends fluidity and strength – what Parks calls “an oceanic” quality, producing waves of energy for the pianist to alternately ride and dive into. 'Find the Way' has the aura of a piano-trio recording in the classic mold, from melody-rich opener “Adrift” to the closing title track, a cover of a romantic tune Parks grew to love on an LP by Rosemary Clooney (Official) and Nelson Riddle. Parks also drew inspiration for this album from the likes of Alice Coltrane and Shirley Horn (for whom Hart played); space and subtlety are a priority.

New release: 'The Dreamer Is the Dream' by Chris Potter  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2pYjFSz Get the CD + 180g Vinyl: http://bit.ly/2oY6l13  For his third ECM release as a leader, Chris Potter presents a new acoustic quartet that naturally blends melodic rhapsody with rhythmic muscle. The group includes superlative musicians well known to followers of ECM’s many recordings from New York over the past decade: keyboardist David Virelles, bassist Joe Martin and drummer Marcus Gilmore, who each shine in addition to the leader on multiple horns. 'The Dreamer Is the Dream' features Potter on tenor saxophone – the instrument that has made him one of the most admired players of his generation – in the striking opener “Heart in Hand” and such album highlights as “Yasodhara,” as well as on soprano sax (“Memory and Desire”) and bass clarinet (the title track). Potter is an artist who “employs his considerable technique in service of music rather than spectacle,” says The New Yorker, and his composing develops in texture and atmosphere with every album. Along with his previous ECM releases, 'Imaginary Cities' and 'The Sirens', he has appeared on some of the label’s most acclaimed discs, including Paul Motian’s classic 'Lost in a Dream' and Dave Holland’s Grammy Award-winning 'What Goes Around'.

'Crystal Silence' by Chick Corea and Gary Burton is reissued on 180g vinyl • Get the LP: http://bit.ly/2o9vc0D •  The Corea/Burton duo was brought together by producer Manfred Eicher, and 'Crystal Silence' (recorded in 1972) brought a new chamber music sensibility into jazz improvisation, distinguished by an effervescence of melody and countermelody, with synchronized cascades of sound in continually changing harmonic movement. “It becomes a little magical,” said Corea.   “'Crystal Silence' is an album of extraordinary musicianship and rare beauty. Rarely have two musicians been so perfectly matched and rarely do we hear an album of such consistent excellence and originality.“ – Stereo  Photo: Patrick Hinely

New release: 'Silent Light' by Dominic Miller  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2oMb88l Get the CD & 180g Vinyl: http://bit.ly/2p901CS iTunes: http://bit.ly/2kxjf7j  Born in Argentina to an American father and Irish mother, guitarist Dominic Miller was raised in the U.S. from age 10 and then educated there and in England. Now he lives in France, though he has toured the globe for the past three decades. Aptly, 'Silent Light' – Miller’s ECM debut, featuring him solo and with percussion accompaniment – has a very international feel, with the Latin influence strong in such pieces as “Baden” (dedicated to Brazilian guitarist-composer Baden Powell). “Le Pont” has an early 20th-century Parisian air, while “Valium” evokes Celtic tunes in the vein of Bert Jansch (Official) and “Fields of Gold” is a hushed instrumental take on one of Sting’s best-known ballads. Miller has long been known as Sting’s right-hand man on guitar – and co-writer of the worldwide hit “Shape of My Heart,” among others. Miller has also worked with the likes of Paul Simon, The Chieftains and Placido Domingo. The guitarist’s playing has prompted praise from Simon, who points out, in a liner note to the album, that Miller “has a beautiful touch, with a fragrance of jazz and English folk.”

New release: 'Nuit blanche' by the Tarkovsky Quartet  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2p4DsPM Get the CD: http://bit.ly/2nNFFii iTunes: http://bit.ly/2mNd252  Ingmar Bergman once said of Andrey Tarkovskiy , Андрей Тарковский, “He moves with such naturalness in the room of dreams,” and the French-German quartet named after the great Russian filmmaker has developed an associative dream-language of its own. For leader and pianist Francois Couturier the “silence and slowness of Tarkovsky” are closely related to an “ECM aesthetic” further developed on the group’s third album 'Nuit blanche', produced by Manfred Eicher in Lugano in April 2016. Here pieces variously composed by François Couturier, or created in the moment by Couturier, cellist Anja Lechner Cello, saxophonist Jean-marc Larché and accordionist Jean-Louis Matinier, explore the texture of dreams and memory and continue to make oblique reference to Tarkovsky. Whether playing improvised chamber music, modern composition or baroque music, the creative originality of the Tarkovsky Quartet shines through.

Today would have been the 85th birthday of the great Russian filmmaker Andrei Arsenjewitsch Tarkowski, an abiding influence on ECM’s musicians. Arvo Pärt’s album 'Arbos' was dedicated to Tarkovsky, so too Jan Garbarek’s 'All Those Born With Wings'. In 2005 Francois Couturier recorded 'Nostalghia – Song for Tarkovsky', together with Anja Lechner, Jean-Louis Matinier and Jean-marc Larché, a group henceforth known as the Tarkovsky Quartet. This week sees the release of 'Nuit Blanche', a new album by the group. In the liner notes, Carolin Emcke suggests that from its opening moments it “exerts a magical attraction that casts a spell on its listeners and sweeps them away. It’s as inimitable as Tarkovsky’s own imagery, which holds viewers in thrall and never lets go.”   The Tarkovsky Quartet begins a tour this Friday:

“Whenever [Dominic Miller] plays the guitar, he creates color, a complete spectrum of emotions, sonic architecture built of silence as well as resonance. He lifts the spirit into higher realms.” (Sting) "Silent Light" is available for pre-order! Get the CD: http://smarturl.it/SilentLight_Amz  iTunes - http://smarturl.it/SilentLight_iTu

New release: 'December Avenue' by Tomasz Stańko New York Quartet  Learn more: http://bit.ly/2nE4Fur  Get the CD: hyperurl.co/h2nyt4  Four years after the landmark album 'Wisława', the great Polish trumpeter Tomasz Stanko’s New York Quartet returns with another masterful recording, 'December Avenue'. Always an insightful bandleader, Stanko here encourages spirited improvisation to flower around his characteristically melancholic and soulful themes, and all players are presented to best advantage. New band member Reuben Rogers – originally from the Virgin Islands and perhaps best-known for his work with Charles Lloyd – is a splendid addition to the team, establishing a profound understanding  with Cuban-born pianist David Virelles and Detroit drummer Gerald Cleaver. JazzTimes, reviewing the band in concert, reflected on the strengths of the individual players: “Stanko has never had a piano player like Virelles. When his moments came, he configured his own lyrical domain within the world of a Stanko song. For that matter, Stanko has never had a bassist and drummer like Rogers and Cleaver, with their hard edges and their volatile energy.” 'December Avenue' was recorded at Studios La Buissonne in the South of France in June 2016 and produced by Manfred Eicher.

Die Gastgeber Dima und Yulya aus St. Petersburg lieben es, Gäste zu empfangen. Vor allem während der sogenannten White Nights - den längsten Tagen des Jahres - erleben Reisende Russland in ganz neuem Licht. Wenn die Sonne 19 Stunden scheint, breitet sich ihre Wärme in der Region langsam aus und bringt die Stadt mit ihren zahlreichen kulturellen Events zum Pulsieren. Zum heutigen internationalen Weltfrauentag feiern wir gemeinsam mit allen Frauen weltweit.  Mary ist über 70, lebt in London und empfängt als Gastgeberin auf Airbnb oft weibliche Gäste, die ihr ein Gefühl von Gemeinschaft und Zusammengehörigkeit vermitteln: „Es ist völlig egal woher die Frauen kommen oder wie alt sie sind. Irgendwas haben wir immer gemeinsam – wir sind schließlich Frauen.“

Der Pariser Vorort Pantin gilt als das neue „Brooklyn“ der Stadt: Getreidemühlen und Fabriken aus dem 19. Jahrhundert reihen sich an ungewöhnliche Häuschen aus einer längst vergangenen Zeit. Zwischen neuen Kunstgalerien und lokalen „Guinguette“-Tavernen liegen mittlerweile auch die Ateliers einiger französischer Luxusmarken. Leben wie im Film – davon träumst du schon ne halbe Ewigkeit?  Dann tagge deine Freunde hier und verrate uns, in welchem Film ihr schon immer mal leben wolltet.   #LiveInTheMovies

Lampions und ein kleiner, knisternder Ofen in der Nacht. Pferde, Gänse und Ziegen auf der riesigen Wiese vor dem Haus am Tag. Was braucht man eigentlich mehr für eine perfekten Familien-Auszeit?  Foto IG @sarimarissa

Eine Unterkunft mit Blick auf die Skyline ist perfekt, um einen ersten Eindruck von New York zu gewinnen. „Im Frühjahr haben wir dieses Apartment wieder gemietet, und diesmal kommen wir mit der ganzen Familie“, erklärt Elisa.  Egal ob es ein Ausblick, eine Wohnung, ein Stadtviertel oder ganz New York ist, es ist einfach etwas ganz Besonderes, deinen Kindern deine Lieblingsdinge zu zeigen.   Folge @etdieucrea auf Instagram und entdecke weitere Familienabenteuer.

20.000 Meilen unter dem Meer - wer von euch hat's gelesen?  Wenn man sich hier am Strand von Le Crotoy mal umschaut, versteht man nämlich recht schnell, wieso Jules Verne ausgerechnet in der französischen Baie de la Somme auf die Idee für seinen berühmten Roman gekommen ist. #LiveThere  📷  IG @burnmebaby

"Gerade jetzt ist es wichtig, aufzustehen und einzustehen für eine Welt in der alle dazugehören. Gegenseitige Akzeptanz kann uns verbinden. Wir sitzen im selben Boot, auch wenn es sich vielleicht nicht immer so anfühlt."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Seid dabei airbnb.de/weaccept  #weaccept

"Wenn Paris die Stadt der Liebe ist, dann ist der Iran für mich das Land der Liebe. An kaum einem anderen Ort auf der Welt habe ich so viel Liebe in der Luft gespürt wie dort." erzählt uns Ryan Junee nach seinem Besuch  im letzten Herbst. "Die Leute, die ich dort kennen lernen durfte, zählen zu den freundlichsten, kulturbegeistertsten und intelligentesten Menschen, die ich kenne."  📷  IG @omidscheybani #weaccept

“Öfter habe ich das Gefühl, dass die Leute länger brauchen, um mich zu erkennen – um zu sehen, wer ich wirklich bin,  Dass sie erstmal realisiere müssen, dass ich viel mehr bin als eine schwarze Frau. Dass ich ein Mensch mit eigenen Ideen und Träumen bin. Richtig akzeptiert fühle ich mich, wenn ich tiefe und aufrichtige Gespräche auch mit Menschen führen kann, die komplett anders sind als ich: andere Geschichte und Gesinnung, andere Religion, andere Hautfarbe. Wenn dann nach einem solchen Gespräch ein gutes Gefühl bei beiden bleibt. Auch wenn das vielleicht nur kurze Momente sind. Für mich bedeuten sie jedes Mal echt viel. Durch sie fühle ich mich zugehörig und wirklich akzeptiert."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit airbnb.de /weaccept   #weaccept

“Um andere akzeptieren zu können, braucht es ein gewisses Grundvertrauen in die Menschen, finde ich. Die Gay-Bar, die ich in Osaka eigentlich besuchen wollte, war zu. Darum bin ich nach nebenan. Trotz einiger Sprachprobleme wurde ich superschnell in die Gespräche an der Theke eingebunden und gefragt woher ich komme. Zögerlich erzählte ich, dass ich eigentlich in die andere Bar wollte. Denn natürlich hatte ich Angst, in der Hetero-Runde anzuecken. Aber keiner fand es der Rede wert. Niemand hat mich komisch angeschaut, weil ich schwul bin.  Die Gay-Bar hat dann später am Abend aufgemacht und wir sind alle zusammen hin und später sogar gemeinsam zum Essen gegangen. Ich habe unzählige coole Tipps für Osaka von meinen neuen Bekannten bekommen. Ab und zu schreiben wir uns noch heute. Dieser Moment, als ich einfach so akzeptiert und in die Runde aufgenommen wurde, war so unfassbar wertvoll für mich.  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt: airbnb.de/accept   #weaccept

"In einer offenen und fortschrittlichen Gesellschaft ist es unser aller Pflicht, jeden willkommen zu heißen, zu akzeptieren und zu integrieren – egal woher sie oder er kommt."   Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept

"Dass man Menschen, die man nicht kennt, als potentielle Freunde betrachtet und nicht als etwas, dem man ausweicht – das bedeutet für mich Offenheit. Mit dieser Einstellung durchs Leben zu gehen verändert Leute. Man sieht es echt in ihren Augen."  Akzeptanz beginnt mit uns allen. Hilf mit. airbnb.com/weaccept  #weaccept

"In der Schule hab ich mich oft so gefühlt, als würde ich nicht richtig reinpassen. Kein Kind hatte eine andere Hautfarbe. Eines Tages kamen zwei extrem coole Jungs in meine Klasse, die aussahen wie ich. Natürlich wurden wir Freunde und nach und nach lernte ich, meine Hautfarbe wertzuschätzen. Ich habe gelernt, wirklich stolz auf mich und meine Herkunft zu sein."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept

"2003 war ich im Irak und habe für die Sicherheit von Journalisten gesorgt, als unser Gebiet durch Aufständische unter Beschuss geriet. Niemals werde ich diese krassen Momente vergessen, in denen ich mich so zugehörig gefühlt habe, obwohl ich Todesangst hatte. Die irakische Familie, bei der wir damals waren, hat alles in ihrer Macht stehende getan, um uns zu schützen."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept

"Als ich zum erstem Mal im Heimatland meiner Eltern war, kam kein Gefühl der Zugehörigkeit auf. Mein Farsi war viel zu schlecht und ich dachte, jeder findet mich komisch, weil ich in den USA aufgewachsen bin. Aber damit lag ich falsch. Ich wurde mit so viel Liebe aufgenommen. Familienmitglieder, Freunde der Familie, Bekannte, Nachbarn, sogar Fremde auf dem Wochenmarkt – alle waren so offen, interessiert und aufrichtig nett zu mir."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept
"Wenn man mich nicht anders behandelt, obwohl ich anders aussehe, fühle ich mich wirklich akzeptiert."   Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept

"Liebe wird bei mir groß geschrieben. Das trage ich auch nach außen. Wer das Gute sehen möchte, findet es. Mit liebevollen Augen auf die Welt und die Menschen zu schauen, verändert alles. Denn schließlich sind wir doch alle Menschen. Niemand ist perfekt. Wir alle lieben, leiden und lachen – egal welche Farbe unsere Haut hat und woran wir glauben. Es gibt für jeden von uns einen Platz in dieser Welt."  Gemeinsam für Zusammenhalt. Helft mit. airbnb.de/accept  #weaccept

Was darf im wilden Westen Montanas auf gar keinen Fall fehlen?   Richtig: Pferde. Gleich hinter den Chico Hot Springs könnt ihr euch in den Sattel schwingen und sanft wipppend die wunderbare Aussicht ins Paradise Valley genießen.  #LiveThere

Es hat auch Vorteile, wenn dein Kind dich in aller Herrgottsfrühe weckt:  - der Natur beim Erwachen zuhören inkl. privatem Sonnenaufgang - dass das Anziehen mal wieder ewig dauert, macht gaaar nichts  - die Schaukel auf dem Spielplatz ist permanent frei - um 11 habt ihr bereits 5 Mal Verstecken gespielt und 3 Tiere beobachtet  #LiveThere 📷  IG @pathsofdesign

Schonmal von Befana, der Weihnachtshexe gehört? Nein?  Also: In Italien fliegt heute Nacht zum Fest Epiphanie eine freundliche Hexe auf ihrem Besen über die Dächer. Dort wo sie landet, beschert sie den Kindern Geschenke. Als Dankeschön stellt man ihr ein Gläschen Wein bereit. Einen Top-Ausblick auf jegliche Flugobjekte werdet ihr hier, am Comer See, mit Sicherheit haben.

Vegan auf Reisen - manchmal nicht ganz unkompliziert.  In Berlin Kreuzkölln wird's euch aber garantiert leicht gemacht. Denn vermutlich findet sich in ganz Europa keine Gegend mit mehr veganen Köstlichkeiten als hier an der Grenze zwischen Kreuzberg und Neukölln.  Falls euch beim Städtetrip in die Hauptstadt der süße Zahn tropft, probiert bitte die himmlischen Donuts von Brammibal's Donuts #Veganuary

Hallo 2017!  Was gibt's Schöneres, als das neue Jahr mit besten Aussichten zu begrüßen? Alles richtig gemacht, liebe Lena. 🌎

Wer den letzten Abend von 2016 in Schottland verbringt, darf sich hoffentlich über spontanen Besuch freuen: Man sagt sich dort nämlich, dass der erste Besucher im neuen Jahr Glück bringt. In deinem gemütlichen Nest mitten im Wald fühlst du dich frei wie ein Vogel. Lass dich vom Gesang deiner gefiederten Freunde wecken, während die ersten Sonnenstrahlen sanft durch das Grün der Blätter fallen. Wohin fliegst du als Nächstes?  #TreehouseTuesday

Happy Saint Andrew’s Day, liebes Schottland!  Zu Ehren von Sankt Andreas werden heute in allen Städten des Landes rauschende Feste gefeiert. Pack den Strickpulli ein, schnür deine Wanderstiefel und mach dich auf den Weg zu deinem Baumhaus. Mit einer Thermoskanne Kaffee im Rucksack kannst du hier im Wald das herbstliche Farbenspiel genießen.  #TreehouseTuesday

Mark’s In and Out wirkt wie ein Relikt aus den 50er-Jahren – und genau das ist es auch. Das Schnellrestaurant ist seit über 60 Jahren eine echte Institution in Livingston, Montana.  Die Kundschaft ist bunt gemischt und besteht meist aus Einheimischen, die hier immer ein leckeres Abendessen zu günstigen Preisen finden. Besonders beliebt sind die frittierten Champignons und ein echter Retro-Klassiker: Orangenlimonade mit einer Kugel Softeis. Immer noch Hunger? Dann probiert doch noch den Pizza-Burger!  #LiveThere

Die Ruhe trügt. Aber auch am Abend schlägt hier dein Herz höher. Dann kannst du nämlich auf dem Balkon deines Airbnb den atemberaubenden Sonnenuntergang beobachten.  #LiveThere  Foto: IG @zoeoc
Ein Wohnmobil bringt dich ans Ziel deiner Reiseträume – auch wenn es nicht mehr rollt.  #LiveThere  Foto: IG @jiaouyang

M steht für M____ _______  Wir alle haben einen Lieblings-Travel-Buddy. Die eine Person, die in jeder neuen Stadt die magischsten Orte aufspürt – und dich jedes Mal rettet, wenn du fast deinen Reisepass vergisst. Zusammen seid ihr unschlagbar. Auf Spanisch gibt es für ein solches Dreamteam einen ganz besonderen Ausdruck, der für "Seelenverwandte" steht.  Weißt du, welches Sprichwort wir suchen? Vielleicht fragst du ja deine bessere Hälfte um Rat ...

Eine neue Sprache zu lernen ist gar nicht so leicht. In England, wo leidenschaftlich gerne übers Wetter philosophiert wird, kann man zum Beispiel sagen: Es regnet Katzen und Hunde, "it's raining cats and dogs". Damit ist gemeint: Es regnet in Strömen.  Zum Glück können dir unsere Freunde bei EF Deutschland - Sprachreisen eine ganze Palette landestypischer Sätze beibringen. Wenn du das nächste Mal in London unterwegs bist, kannst du deine Reisebegleiter dann stilecht an ihren Regenschirm erinnern. Weil es Katzen und Hunde regnet.
☀️  Happy holiday, liebe Lena Gercke 🌴

Santorini ist quasi das, was ein riesiger Vulkanausbruch vor über 3600 Jahren hinterlassen hat: Die Schönheit der Kykladen im Ägäischen Meer.  Heute liegt die glitzernde Lagune gediegen in der Sonne. Umgeben von strahlend weißen Höhlen und pittoresker Architektur. "Hoch oben über Tiflis thront die Statue einer Frau. Mit der einen Hand prostet sie Gästen zu, mit der anderen vertreibt sie Feinde. Das perfekte Sinnbild einer Stadt, die viele Unruhen erlebt hat und Gastfreundschaft groß schreibt. Drei Tage in Tiflis waren für mich: Kultur ohne Ende, wandeln zwischen bröckelnden Sowjet-Denkmälern, entspannte Schwefelbäder, Grillen mit neuen Freunden. Wahnsinn, wie diese uralte Stadt immer weiter ins 21. Jahrhundert hineinwächst." #LiveThere  Fotografin Chantal Anderson über ihren #Airbnb Trip nach Tiflis

Schonmal von Tiflis gehört?  Falls nicht, hier eine kleine Zusammenfassung: Hauptstadt Georgiens am Kaukasus, Heimat von Khachapuri and Chacha mit Wahnsinns-Flohmärkten, antiken Badehäusern und coolsten Technoclubs.  #LiveThere #Fernweh  http://abnb.co/jR8DnL

Wann ist man in einer Stadt zuhause? Wenn man alle lokalen Spezialitäten probiert und lange dort gelebt hat? Wenn man sich gehörig verlaufen und trotzdem nach Hause gefunden hat?   Wir finden, dass man eine Stadt nicht kennenlernt, wenn man sie anhand einer To-Do-Liste abhakt und in den immergleichen Hotelzimmern übernachtet. Auch nicht beim Schlangestehen vor Sehenswürdigkeiten. Sind es nicht oft die Menschen, Orte und Plätze, die uns zufällig begegnen, welche uns dann tatsächlich in Erinnerung bleiben?   Um diesen Fragen auf den Grund zu gehen, haben wir uns mit dem Kreuzberger Künstlerkollektiv 44flavours zusammen getan und sind mit Berlinern um die Häuser gezogen. Wir haben ihre Geschichten gehört und ihre Herzensorte besucht.    44flavours hat diese Berlinmomente in eine Ausstellung gegossen. Entstanden ist das Berlin #LiveThere Haus – ein Ort zum Zusammenkommen, Entdecken, Mitmachen – und mit ihm eine Ausstellung, die von den Geschichten der Berliner lebt: Mit dabei sind zum Beispiel der Autor Michael Nast und die Food-Expertin Mary Scherpe von Stil in Berlin, oder die jungen Modekennerinnen und Mamas Nike und Sarah von This is Jane Wayne und die Choreographin Nikeata Thompson.   *************************************************************************  Kommt vorbei und macht mit. Eine Anmeldung zu den kostenlosen Sessions & Workshops ist nicht nötig.   Donnerstag, 14. Hasan Nadir – homosexuell, Moslem, Autor des Buches "Gott in Pink" Chase Blodgett – transgender, Hockeyspieler  Park Cannon – queer, schwarz, weiblich, Mitglied des Abgeordnetenhauses  Geschichten wie ihre beeindrucken und berühren. Vintage Shopping in Shimokitazawa: gebongt. Japanische Nudeln selber machen: gerne. Tokios merkwürdige Köstlichkeiten probieren: klaro. Shochu Cocktails mit deinem Airbnb Gastgeber: はい  Wo immer du hinfährst, sei dort zuhause. Auch wenn's nur für eine Nacht ist. #LiveThere

In L.A. kommst du an. Und die goldene Abendsonne verzaubert dich. Den besten Smoothie-Shop findest du am zweiten Tag und wirst gleich zum Stammgast. Joggen am Venice Beach? Klar! Dass dieses "California-Life" so easy und entspannt ist, überrascht dich nicht.  Wo immer du hinfährst, sei dort zuhause. Auch wenn's nur für eine Nacht ist. #LiveThere

Die Leute in Paris sind einfach zu spannend, um sie nicht ausgiebig zu beobachten. Das geht perfekt am Canal St. Martin. Danach hast du Hunger? Keine Sorge: Deine Gastgeber bringen dir doch heute Abend bei, wie man Crêpes macht.   Wo immer du hinfährst, sei dort zuhause. Auch wenn's nur für eine Nacht ist. #LiveThere

"Die schöne Atmosphäre, die mein Vater in seiner Wohnung in Wien geschaffen hat, wollte ich unbedingt erhalten. Er ist nach Malta gezogen und dann stand die Wohnung direkt neben meiner leer." erzählt Julia, die letzten Sommer ihre ersten Airbnb Gäste begrüßt hat.  "Am meisten überrascht und gefreut hat mich, dass alles, was ich von Herzen für Gäste mache, auch ihnen direkt ins Herz geht. Ich mag es einfach, mich ständig weiter zu entwickeln und jeder Airbnb Gast trägt dazu auch ein Stückchen bei." erfahren wir von ihr. Und natürlich ist Julia auch ziemlich froh darüber, dass sie als Studentin keinen Nebenjob mehr braucht, um ihren Abschluss zu finanzieren."  #AirbnbHostStories

Wer für ein paar Tage in Tokio leben möchte, sollte auf keinen Fall Point No. 39 verpassen. Ein unglaublich cooler Ort, besonders wenn man Antiquitäten liebt. Achtet mal bitte auf die uralte und restaurierte Singer Nähmaschine. Woahhh. #LiveThere
Ach übrigens: In Paris lebst du, wenn du den fantastischen, tollen, wunderschönen und unvergesslichen Blick vom Palais de Tokio gesehen hast. Hach ja. #LiveThere
Für jede seiner Erfindungen ein eigenes Zimmer. Einzig beim Aufräumen wäre ein bisschen Hilfe nötig. Aber das macht nix.  Welcher Superheld wird sich hier wie zuhause fühlen?
Eine kleine Farm umgeben von saftigen Wiesen und nichts als Ruhe.  Welcher Superheld durfte hier seine Kindheit verbringen?
In einem Land, nicht ganz so weit weit entfernt...legst du dich mit deinem Lieblingsmenschen unter den Sternenhimmel und schaust den drei Monden beim Funkeln zu.   #MayThe4thBeWithYou
Luxus-Strandhaus. Riesen-Terrasse als Landeplatz. Und jede Menge Platz zum Ausspannen.  Welcher Superheld könnte hier wohl zuhause sein?
In L.A. lebst du, wenn dein einziger Plan für den Tag ist, ähhh, ja, was eigentlich? Ach, lass uns einfach genau hier sitzen bleiben. #LiveThere
Ist das noch Urlaub? Oder leb ich schon hier? Wer mit Airbnb in L.A. ist, wird sich diese Fragen vermutlich das eine oder andere mal stellen müssen.  #LiveThere
Selbst wenn du am liebsten festen Boden unter den Füßen hast: bei Sonnenuntergang wird dich der Skatepark in Venice Beach einfach umhauen.  #LiveThere

Untertrieben gesagt: Alexandre ist die französische Gastfreundschaft in Person. Noch bevor du überhaupt bei ihm ankommst, hat er schon längst nach deinem Lieblingskuchen gefragt. Diesen besorgt er dann in der kleinen Patisserie nebenan und platziert ihn zusammen mit einer exzellenten Flasche Wein in deinem Zimmer. Du hast Lust auszugehen? Alexandre zeigt dir die spannendsten Pariser Restaurants und Bars. Du suchst den wirklich allerbesten Käse der Stadt? Alexandre verrät dir das Geheimnis. Aber Psst.  So geht also #LiveThere
Ein Leben zwischen Eulen, Füchsen und frischem Gemüse. Jorg und Helena haben sich ihre Welt im perfekten Einklang mit der Natur aufgebaut. Und Airbnb Gäste dürfen natürlich daran teilhaben. #Earthday
Einen eigenen ökologischen Olivenhain. Ernten direkt hinter dem Haus. Solarenergie und nur die besten lokalen Lebensmittel für die Gäste.  Wie wichtig ist euch ein nachhaltiges Leben? #Earthday2016

Hallo Welt!  Heute ist #EarthDay2016 – also lasst uns gemeinsam daran erinnern, den wunderschönen Planeten Erde besser zu schützen & gut auf ihn aufzupassen.   Danke Thomas, dass du mit allerbestem Beispiel voran gehst.

In L.A. fährt man immer Auto, sagen viele. Wenn man allerdings direkt in Venice Beach lebt, darf man diese Regel auch gerne mal brechen: indem man einfach den Strand entlang spaziert und den ganzen neuen Nachbarn Hallo sagen geht. #LiveThere
Thank you, Slanted Blog Magazine! 😍

In the past week we found out that one of artist Stefan Marx' favourite events every year is NY Art Book Fair by Printed Matter, Inc. and that he will - amongst other things - talk about drawings of and zines about planes at #Indiecon2017. Stefan, we hope you'll enjoy Indiecon just as much (we're pretty excited already) and thanks for taking over the channel! Now Rose Nordin from OOMK Zine (One of my kind is a zine Stack calls "a zine made by a group of British Muslim women, who use it to give a totally original and subtly nuanced perspective on contemporary culture") will take you through the week. At Indiecon, Rose will be part of the panel about feminist magazines. Welcome, Rose - have fun! ❤️ #indiemagstakeover: www.instagram.com/indiemags

Last week Steve from Stack took us on a little office tour and we had a look behind the Stack-scenes. Thanks for showing us around, Steve - we're very excited for your talk at #indiecon2017 with Steve Anglesey from The New European, a magazine that was published less than two weeks after the #brexit! This week artist Stefan Marx will take over the account - welcome to his weirdly wonderful world: www.instagram.com/indiemags

To win a #Stackmagazines subscription, scroll through the latest pictures at our Instagram account and tell us the movie and the name of the artist who made the illustration. First one to get them all right in the comments below this instagram-posting wins: https://www.instagram.com/p/BXFgjrkH3IP/

We're passing the baton to an Indiecon-oldie-but-goldie: wonderful Steve from Stack who is an Indiemag-encyclopedia on two legs. Welcome to London! Steve is taking over the Indiecon Instagram for the next few days, sharing a few of the magazines and things he has got going on at stack, deep in the bowels of Somerset House. Come on down the winding stairs and join him in his magazine home...www.instagram.com/indiemags

In the past week Ryan Fitzgibbon from Hello Mr. introduced us to his new magazine residency called "The Issues!" which ties in with hellomr.'s general quest to reflect on the wide spectrum of the LGBTQ community. Through Ryan we met the first magazine-in-residence: BRUNCHCLUBNY by the lovely boys Ernest and Colby who are exploring the lives of queer people of colour. Support their Kickstarter campaign for the first print issue which will portray voices that need to be heard - now more than ever if you ask us. Thanks so much for showing us your world, guys! Ryan, can't wait to hear more about "The Issues!" at #indiecon2017. Another magazine that gives voice to an important topic is Migrant Journal. We're very happy to welcome Isabel and Justinien for the next #indiemagstakeover — have fun! instagram.com/indiemags

Last week we dipped our Indie-toes into the Chinese publishing world through the eyes of Nelson from LOST Magazine (THANK YOU!). This week Ryan Fitzgibbon from Hello Mr. in New York will introduce us to his world on www.instagram.com/indiemags. He dedicates his first posting to the #G20-performance of 1000 GESTALTEN:  "Hello, indie mag lovers. It’s the Hello Mr. team here, taking over your feed for the week! We launched our first issue in 2012 to create a platform for emerging queer talent and unheard voices in the LGBTQ, but our fight is a for all human rights. We were inspired by the art collective 1000 GESTALTEN’s powerful performance in the streets of Hamburg during #G20HH summit and wanted to kick off the week by honoring these independent artists creating conversation through there work. More to come. Thank you! 🌹✊🏽

In the weeks before Indiecon 2017 we are asking Indiecon speakers to give us an insight into their world and their work... Nelson Ng from LOST Magazine which is based in China will make a start. Check out instagram.com/indiemags and have a good week! #indiefirst

Welcome to the Internet: Indiecon 2017 – www.indiefirst.de This year's topic is "Impact - magazines that make a difference" because we can’t keep sitting on our asses while others define the values of our future society. Check out our first speakers and save your ticket here:

#mondaymagazine: perdizmagazine from Barcelona is a bilingual "magazine about things that make people happy". Here's a list of things that made us exceptionally happy leafing through their latest issue: a photo series of hilariously fake smiles, a portrait of Tim Cockerill, owner of an impressive flea circus (his favourite flea's name: Fifi) and the story of Peruvian Abel Cruz titled "The Cloud-Gatherer" who, as a child, had to walk great distances in order to fetch water during dry seasons. Nowadays, he collects mist with nets which then flows through pipes into collection tanks. As the makers of perdiz put it: "Just because your dreams are unlikely, don't let anyone tell you they're impossible." Right on! 😍✊

#magazinemonday: Fathers is an indiemag from Poland dedicated to fatherhood. Editor-in-chief Marcin Krasny in his editor's note claims that being a young parent is comparable "to the circumstances Robinson Crusoe found himself in when he was stranded in a strange place that he had to rediscover from scratch." Sounds about right. In the latest issue we meet male midwifes and two men who help disavantaged youth in their own way - one by teaching them how to box, the other by doing survival trips into the woods. And there's a touching interview with Kati Herbert whose father, Sir Wally Herbert who is one of the greatest Arctic explorers, moved the little family to a small Inuit village when she was just a baby. Oh, and a little reminder to all the Germans out there: it's Father's Day on Thursday. 👨👴❤️

#magazinemonday: Athleta Magazine from Italy is a magazine dedicated to photography focussing on sporting culture. It's neither glossy sports brands ads nor portraits of triumphing football stars but a fresh take on sports photography. It's about "a journey in the principle of resilience". Fittingly, there's an incredible series about Beatrice Vio, a Paralymics gold medal-winning fencer. Athela also takes us to Myanmar for some rounds of Lethwei, the Burmese bareknuckle fight, and to Basketball courts across the globe. 💪 ✌️🏆
Are you in?

#mondaymagazine: Wavesandwoodsmagazin combines surfing, travelling and the ourdoors with the goal to serve its readers as inspiration for their next adventure. In their first issue they take you on a motorcross trip to Indonesia's best surf spots, go fishing in Alaska with three-time surf World Champion Mick Fanning who is involved with the environmental organization WildArk, talk to Slovenian photographer Anze Osterman who portraits people all over the world who live an autarkic life. And we meet Alex Bellini who wants to raise awareness for climate change and plans on floating on an ice berg in the Artic Ocean in a survival capsule - until the ice has completely melted. Sounds like a plan, hm? 🌊

#mondaymagazine: J'AIPUR Journal from New York is a East-meets-West magazine "for creative and curious minds". In an interview with one of the last globemakers Peter Bellery who is also involved in charity auto-rickshaw races through India to raise awareness for the elephant plight we learn that while one of his globes will soon hang in the Louvre he dreams of getting one of his masterpieces into a Wes Anderson movie. New Delhi-based photographer Serena Chopra takes us on a trip through Bhutan exploring how the kingdom's people "move towards modernity in a mindful way". Scottish artist Olivia Fraser lives in Delhi and London and paints hypnotic and painstakingly perfect chakras and lotuses: "My subject matter is about a search for inner peace (...), I find creating these works with their iterative detail and slow process involves a form of patience, concentration and contemplation very akin to the tools one uses for yoga." Namaste!  🙏

#mondaymagazine: PANTA is an indiemag based in Berlin and Lisbon and is all about "artivism", as they call it. They tell stories about artists from all over the world who use their craft for a good cause. For example, it features Iranian photographer Hoda Afshar who explores identity and migration in her series "In the Exodus, I love you more", gives an insight into the projects of Zentrum für Politische Schönheit (Center for Political Beauty), talks in depth to South Sudanese artist Atong Atem (whose work is also on the cover) about reclaiming space and identity - the reason she became so attached to photographing "especially African folks". She says: "Knowing the history of ethnographic photography in Africa and across the colonised world is motivation for me to take my claim to this medium that's been used against us for so long. I'm motivated by reclamation but also celebration. We are beautiful people with beautiful cultures and I want to show that off." And she sure does. Each artists presented in the magazine "has at some point encountered a lack of awareness, information or representation (...) and we honour them for having the vision and the perseverance to transform that emptiness into something tangible, beautiful and meaningful." Go read PANTA, it will leave you a little more hopeful. ✊🏼✊🏽✊🏾✊🏿

#mondaymagazine: Cameo Kollektiv's latest issue of "Cameo" is a multi-lingual (German, English, Spanish, Arabic, Farsi, Tigrinva) approach to the concept of "arriving" and came about in weekly meetings that, in total, more than 70 people participated in. It's a great collection of essays, poems, interviews and photo series shedding light from a myriad of different perspectives on what it means to arrive within yourself, at a crossroads, in a new society. The content is highly subjective and that's where its strength lies. The goal was to "broaden the topic of 'arrival' and shift the focus from 'integration' and 'dominant cultures' to something that affects each and everyone of us". 🔀 🔁 ↩️↔️

#mondaymagazine: STAPLE Magazine from London is „a magazine for the curious“. The first issue’s theme is „Dizziness of Youth“ and tries to capture this „feeling of light-headedness“ that accompanies growing up. There is an intimate photo series about teenagers living in a youth detention centre in northern Czech Republic, an interview about coming-of-age movies (Hello Clueless!), a „Salinger literary walk“ through New York (Hello The Catcher in the Rye!), a 21-step guide titled „How to Stare into Blank Space“ (Hello everyday life!). Staple’s makers see youth as „an experience (...) marked by its contradictions and volatility; a period of not one but multiple transitions of different magnitudes“. Going through the magazine is a little walk down memory lane... Oh, to be or not be... young again? 👧👦 ➡️ 👩 👨

#mondaymagazine: Migrant Journal is a six-issue publication what re-thinks the concept of migration and was founded by four "enthusiastic Europeans" holding four passports from four different nations yet living in two countries of which they do not hold nationalities. It's supposed to be "an intellectual response to the migrant crisis, an artistic counterpoint to the rise of far-right extremisms, a critical reassessment of a global space made of migrations, movements, and exchanges." The first issue focusses on the impact of migration on rural areas. As Steve from Stack points out: "They carry on this idea of showing negative spaces and things that are not there; making the invisible visible is a very important part of this magazine." The contributors are designers, philosophers, researchers, artists, urbanists, journalists and academics - and you can tell: It really is bursting with information and interesting angles and fresh perspectives. Highly, highly commended! 🌎 💘

Attention, dearest print lovers! There's an event coming up in Munich that is just as culturally important and interesting as Oktoberfest: EDCH - International Editorial Design Conference formerly known as QVED! 💥  Their line-up with more than 60 speakers is truly mouthwatering: Steve from Stack, Penny and Veronica from The Gentlewoman, Michael from HoppundFrenz, Rob from Delayed Gratification, Lars from Slanted Blog Magazine are coming - just to name a few of our indie favourites. So how about a little trip to Munich next week? 🎒

#mondaymagazine: Libertine Magazin is a German indiemag that revolves around topics like women's empowerment, society at large and queerness. It's supposed to be a breath of fresh air without any labels but a clear attitude towards life: freedom. Editor-in-chief Juliane Rump: "We want to bring together all women - no matter what their sexual orientation, job or social background might be. We want to show all different kinds of role models. Most importantly, we want to make women more visible". Their fourth issue focusses on the vast topic of "future" and is coming out soon - if you happen to be in Berlin or Hamburg on March 11 you can celebrate with them at the Libertine Magazin Party! Great excuse to party... not that you'd need one.🎈
There is a big indiemags-family portrait on Tracks tonight, feat. Die Brueder, MC1R Magazine, Gudberg Nerger, Das Wetter - Magazin für Text und Musik and TISSUE Magazine:

Kommt nach Hamburg zum Indiemagday! Am Hamburger Oberhafen eröffnet zum dritten Mal nach 2015 und 2016 die "Free Trade Zone for Printed Goods"! Kommt rum, bringt eure Magazine, Comics, Zines mit und alle Leute, die ihr kennt. Alle Infos: >>> indiefirst.de <<<  Am letzten Sonntag im August wollen wir die Magazinkultur mit euch hochleben lassen – und den Hamburger Oberhafen in "Magazine Mania" verwandeln. Ihr könnt euer eigenes Heft präsentieren oder eure Magazinsammlung ausmisten, internationale Magazinmacherinnen und Magazinmacher treffen und Heftberge durchstöbern.  Außerdem mit dabei: Kinder-Basteltisch, Happs und Schlürf zu fairen Preisen, DJ, Lese-Ecke und weitere noch namenlose Attraktionen …  Der Indiemagday ist Teil der Indiecon – The Independent Magazine Festival 2017 (indiefirst.de), ein Projekt von Die Brueder.  ///////  Join the #indiemagday and our „Free Trade Zone for Printed Goods" at Hamburg’s „Oberhafen", Halle 4, Stockmeyerstr. 41, 20457 Hamburg. Let’s celebrate the diversity of independent magazines and their smart and fearless micro publishers.  >>> You want to have your own stall? This way, please: indiefirst.de <<<  During the last Sunday in August, we will transform a former warehouse into Magazine Mania. Find collectibles, hidden treasures and special offers. Buy, sell or swap mags, zines, comics and other printed goods.  There will be a huge collection of international indiemags – brought to Hamburg by the makers themselves and some of the most amazing stores in Germany. Come and experience books, posters, postcards and many big or small gifts made of paper. Come and read, dance, talk, eat and drink.  Indiemagday is a project by Die Brueder (LINK) and part of Indiecon – The Independent Magazine Festival 2017: indiefirst.de

#mondaymagazine: Ladybeard is an indiemag from London that is feminist but not just for women. It's "an attempt at liberation" - by giving voices "you won't hear in women's magazines" a platform, voices that deviate from the so-called "ideal". The current issue's theme: the human mind. Ladybeard takes you on an insightful journey. Here are just some of the interesting stops along the way: a photo series about the conversion of former mental institutions (Hello, Tesco!), a software transforming schizophrenic patient's auditory hallucinations into an avatar who talks back at them, an interview with Ben Sessa of Breaking Convention, leader in psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy. So it comes as no surprise that they received a commendation for "Best magazine of the year" at the Stack Awards 2016. Trust us: Really, really worth your while.  🎯

#magazinemonday: BrownieShanghai is a bilingual indiemag from Shanghai named after an iconic camera and with a focus on - you guessed correctly - photography and "how it can change our lives". The main goal is "uncovering the value of photography, and its relevance to everyday life". Through really great and intimate photo series, Brownie explores how photography can show us the invisible connections that make us human. 📸 🔀

#mondaymagazine: Agapornis Magazine is an indiemag from Barcelona "all about the importance of having animals in your life, and how they influence the contemporary culture", Toni, one of the editors-in-chief says. In Agapornis III you'll find a love letter to sea horses, pictures of animal tattoos or a travel report from Morocco featuring lots of stray cats. Agapornis is meant to be for "a new generation whose idea of animals is different from our parents’. (...) Today, animals are considered a real part of the family, not merely mouse-catchers or property guards." Agapornis also gives their readers the chance to purchase the magazine with a 3€ plus going to a different animal charity every volume, in their third one: an organisation taking care of abandoned small mammals like guinea pigs, rabbits or chinchillas. On rainy mondays in times like these, we all need a little more fluffiness in our lives, don't we? 🐰
We just love the cig-mag! The fabulous Nelson (LOST Magazine) shares his indiemag favourites from all over Asia.
Our friends from Do you read me Berlin are looking for staff:

#mondaymagazine: Nang Magazine is an indiemag from Seoul and not your typical cinema magazine reporting on the industry or reviewing the latest movies. Nang's goal is to "broaden the horizon of what the moving image is in Asia". By focussing on screenwriting in their first issue, the magazine makers want "to shed light on an area of filmmaking that is both mysterious and marginalized". They do so with an interview series with 13 writers and writer-directors from countries such as Malaysia, Iran or South Korea. These interviews are interlaced with excerpts of screenplays or - as editor-in-chief Davide calls them - "performances on paper". 📝 🎥

#mondaymagazine: accent is an indiemag from London and a celebration of lives lived outside the ordinary. In their first editorial letter, editors-in-chief Lucy and Lydia tell a story about Nachos and Burning Man closing with: "Every once in a while, when you step outside your life's routine for a moment, you might meet a stranger at a bar, by the side of the road or at a 70,000-strong festival who sits down to share their story with you. This magazine exists to house those stories." In the first issue those are photos and stories of Mexico City street kids in the 90s, an elderly bachelor whose main interest it is to live in "the cheapest house in the state" and who "would be very happy in a neighborhood that nobody else wants" or a New York vogue ballroom star using her stage for HIV activism. Definitely people you should meet. 💘

#mondaymagazine: The Exposed is an indiemag from Copenhagen taking form as a printed magazine and a free app which recognizes images inside the magazine adding "a whole other level of editorial and creative interest" in the form of videos and audio sequences. Their first issue revolves around young photographers examining past and present events relevant to their cultural identity. Stine from Stack says: “Paying respect to the slow pace of print, The Exposed is the closest we’ve seen to a perfect merge between print and digital.” We agree. 🤖

#mondaymagazine: PAX - 6 is an indiemag published by Das Studio, a Cologne-based open network focusing on design, art and creative direction. Here comes a little lesson in biology: PAX - 6 is a member of the Pax gene family and acts as a master control gene for the development of eyes and other sensory organs. A fitting title for a photography magazine, right? 📸

#mondaymagazine: Yuca is a new indiemag from Bogotá which the makers see as "a canvas on which a chosen topic, that we call our alibi, couples with a cross-cutting idea in order to inspire". The first issue, which was nominated for a Stack award, focused on the "gastronomic experience" - be it having dinner at a friend's house or in a fancy restaurant - and "roots" being "the main position from which we relate to others", enabling us "to open up to creativity and movement rather than remaining still and unchanged". Their second issue will revolve around architecture and migration. We're intrigued!

#mondaymagazine: SOLO Skateboard Magazine is an indiemag from Cologne about all things - surprise - skateboarding. After detaching themselves from Monster Skateboard Magazine and its publishing house the makers feel like they don't have to compromise anymore. With their bilingual magazine they want to reflect on what they like and on "what skateboarding is all about". It's only fitting they'd publish independently, isn't it?
Vote for one year of independent entertainment.
Danke, war es! #Glühweinhicks

🎾🎾🎾 #magazinemonday: Racquet is an indiemag from New York celebrating the art, ideas, style and culture surrounding tennis. The Stack awards 2016 nominee (they received a commendation - congrats, well earned!) wants to restore some of the swagger of the "swashbuckling sport of the tennis boom of the 1970s and '80s". Game, set and match! 🎾🎾🎾
Please help making this possible.
Hey fellow Hamburg magazine lovers - no plans for tonight yet? Our friends from Die Epilog are at Gudberg Nerger talking about the past, present and future of their magazine. Drop by! 🎈

#magazinemonday: SOFA magazine is an indiemag from Berlin and its slogan is "Life Is A Chatroom". The Stack awards 2016 nominee wants to uncover and define the now and look into the near future - "exploring one tantalizing, terrifying, tantamount or taboo topic per issue while sitting on a digital and analog sofa with cool and controversial people."   SOFA's look and feel is quite extraordinary, the art directors from studio yukiko "were initially briefed to create a teen mag for the future, inspired by the 90s, to make it both as accessible to 16-year-olds as it is for nostalgic for the 30 plus." In terms of content and design: Mission more than accomplished, if you ask us.

A Syrious Look.  Syrians in Germany: A Magazine about Culture in Exile is a new Indiemag from Berlin, a city which "has blossomed into a new center for Syrian culture abroad". This magazines gives artists and thinkers in exile the possibility to speak their minds; it is not supposed to be "a refugee newspaper" but rather a chronicle of "a remarkable if horrible historical moment (...) that we, Syrians and Berliners alike, are suddenly and unexpectedly sharing". All proceeds are being donated. The first issue will be launched tomorrow and if you're in Berlin, make sure to drop by their launch party! ➡ https://www.facebook.com/events/217381962018653/

Berlin Quarterly is an independent journal with a global perspective combining in-depth reportage, literature and visual culture - "keys to mutual understanding, allowing us to interpret the past and to prepare ourselves for the challenges of the future." Their fifth issue explores the question „What does it mean to be human?“ and will see the light of day this Friday in - guess where?! - Berlin at sodabooks.com. (https://www.facebook.com/events/1611680939133788/) Great venue, great people, great drinks. Let's go!

"Dirty Furniture - When Design Leaves the Showroom" is a finite series of six issues. Each one takes a piece of furniture as its theme and springboard to explore topics spanning politics, design, history, technology, psychology, manufacturing, art and the plain weird. The recent's issue's main focus is on toilets: sanitation in India is investigated, toilet paper unrolled and nappies reconsidered. We say: great (toilet) read! 🚽
Hey Hamburg magazine makers - our friends of Transform Magazin drop by at Gudberg Nerger and there's no reason to miss out on this one. 🙌  https://www.facebook.com/events/339944803032953

Congratulations BLOCK Magazin and 39NULL Magazin für Gesellschaft und Kultur – two Indies went for GOLD at this year's #LeadAwards.

Have you ever dreamt of making your own magazine and didn't quite know how? "So you want to publish a magazine?" by Angharad Lewis covers all the nuts and bolts of indie magazine publishing, from budgeting and distribution to publicity and design. And it features Indiecon-friends-and-family such as The Gentlewoman, The Outpost or Offscreen Magazine. Oh, and there's also a tiny picture from Indiecon 2015. So get a copy of the guide, look for us and learn a lot of useful information on indie publishing on the way.

💰Attention, attention! Anxy Magazine will be a bi-annual magazine about our inner worlds— struggles and fears we all face, some way or another, and the way these fears "fool us into believing that the rest of the world is normal and we’re not". Anxy is neither supposed to be your therapist's scientific journal nor your self-help manual. It won't tell you how to "fix a problem". Rather, it will "cut through the clutter to offer real discussions and striking explorations of the wildcards our brains and bodies throw our way". Sounds more than worthy of support, doesn't it?💰

📷 We've been seeing a bunch of fabulous photography magazines pop up over the past few years (including our friend Rosa's THE SMART VIEW). We had no idea! If you happen to be in cologne this week, step into Museum für Angewandte Kunst Köln and visit Page Impressions with more than 60 participants from all over the world.
To sweeten your Sunday we compiled a small visual review for everybody who was at Indiecon 2016 - and also for the ones who couldn't make it.

Smart people say smart things - for example Nelson Ng of LOST Magazine or Mads Pankow of Die Epilog - in a comprehensive Indiecon review. Listen in at Monocle 24 Radio's print industry show "The Stack". Thanks as well to Steven Watson of Stack Magazines (confusing, guys!) for all the insights and also for sharing what happened in Hamburg.  https://monocle.com/radio/shows/the-stack/

Independent Magazines strive for relevance in content - writes Silke Burmester for Süddeutsche Zeitung. Thanks for the Indiecon review and the exceptional reading list including our friends at Fukt Magazine, Das Buch als Magazin, Elephant Magazine, Flaneur Magazine, Vorn Magazine and FROH! - and our very own gentle rain mag.
